Notes: Schools reopened in September, but schedules have been modified. Classes are now shorter (30-45 min) and larger classes have been split into two sessions.   Teachers at pre-university education level are required to be either vaccinated or show a weekly Covid test certificate  Lecturers and university students are required to be either vaccinated or show a weekly Covid test certificate  Social distancing measures, emphasis on hygiene, and mask-wearing  School year started 2 weeks earlier to allow for repetition of classes for missed content   âVia a video message on Sunday, Minister of Education, Sports and Youth Evis Kushi wished all students and teachers a new successful school year and urged everyone "to respect anti-COVID measures as health is the most important element in these pandemic times."â    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211113141838/http://www.news.cn/english/europe/2021-09/28/c_1310214789.htm

Workplaces have remained opened including essential workplaces e.g. takeout, etc and non-essential e.g. hairdressers but with strict social distancing and cannot operate during curfew hours of 11pm-6am (implemented 1st September)    https://web.archive.org/web/20211113152620/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

Sports championships, the activities of theatres, artistic, cultural performances, and conferences will be allowed with the presence of fans, with a reduced capacity of up to 30% according to the IPH protocol.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211113155019/https://punetejashtme.gov.al/en/information-on-the-movement-of-foreign-nationals-in-albania
Gatherings of up to 50 people allowed outdoors, no change from June 15th 2021     https://web.archive.org/web/20211113152620/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/
Public transport has continued to remain open since 1st June 2020  https://web.archive.org/web/20211113152620/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

Since September 1st, there is a curfew from 11pm to 6am. Only delivery drivers are allowed to travel during this time. No change     https://web.archive.org/web/20211113152620/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/
No restriction on internal movement between cities and regions. No change    https://web.archive.org/web/20211113152620/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

From 6th September 2021 onwards:  International travellers are not required to quarantine but have to present a negative PCR test within 72 hours of departure/vaccination passport  Albanian citizens who do not have a negative test have to self-isolate for 10 days and inform health authorities     https://web.archive.org/web/20211113152620/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

Various economic packages e.g. doubling payment for people receiving unemployment benefits   https://web.archive.org/web/20211113154058/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#A    https://web.archive.org/web/20211113161424/https://financa.gov.al/raporte-per-covid-19/
https://web.archive.org/web/20211113154058/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#A

Public officials urging individuals to comply with guidelines e.g. Minister of Education Evis Kushi urging students to respect and anti-Covid measures (September 2021)  Specific websites for Covid information e.g. coronavirus.al - still in service   There is a hotline for Covid advice for citizens launched by Minister of Health and Social Protection in September 2020, which is still in service     https://web.archive.org/web/20200421103259/https://shendetesia.gov.al/covid-19-manastirliu-linje-e-gjelber-falas-per-keshilla-per-qytetaret/

Testing available for those who show Covid-symptoms, not clear if asymptomatic testing also available   "Currently, to be tested for COVID-19 by the Albanian public health authority one must have symptoms and a recommendation from the public health authorityâs family doctor.  However, private testing labs will perform a test for a fee, and no symptoms or a doctorâs recommendation is required (see details below)."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211113152620/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

This news source implies that contact tracing is happening, HOWEVER there are inconsistencies and delays     https://web.archive.org/web/20211113165231/https://exit.al/en/2021/10/15/albanian-state-audit-finds-testing-delays-lack-of-resources-led-to-spread-of-virus/

Masks required for indoor spaces and public transport.  "It is recommended to keep the mask in all those places where is not possible to keep social distance and for those which have not received the full dose of vaccination"    https://web.archive.org/web/20211113155019/https://punetejashtme.gov.al/en/information-on-the-movement-of-foreign-nationals-in-albania

All individuals above the age of 16+ are eligible for a vaccine     "Albanians can choose between the Chinese Sinovac vaccine, Russiaâs Sputnik, or limited amounts of AstraZeneca and Pfizer."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211113172241/https://www.euractiv.com/section/coronavirus/news/albanian-parliament-agrees-on-mandating-vaccines-for-ministers/

New rules apply in order to access Andorra from outside the EU or similar (e.g. United Kingdom), that you must have proof of either a vaccination certificate - a complete series received more than 14 days ago - recovery from the disease - has passed the COVID in the last 6 months - or a PCR / TMA test with a negative result performed in the last 72 hours before entering the Principality. The document must be carried to show it to the public authorities if they so request. In the event that the authorities detect the entry of people from outside the EU or similar and who do not have the aforementioned documentation, they must carry out a mandatory preventive confinement of 14 days, which may be reduced to 10 if they are made a diagnostic test to detect COVID-19. https://archive.vn/ua9Hj

The following expenses can be funded through the government program:   a) Salary  b) Financial liabilities arising from credit operations with Andorran banks.  c) Investments in the adaptation of establishments for the attention of the public to adapt to the sanitary requirements derived from the sanitary emergency situation caused by the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2.  d) Expenses for the supply of running water, electricity, telephony and heating.  e) Rental costs of commercial premises.  f) Fees for leasing operations (financial leasing) duly formalized.    https://archive.vn/MoxiC

From 18th Oct on, face masks are not required on the street or in outdoor spaces in Andorra. However, if it is not possible to respect physical distancing or a crowd forms, people are requested to wear them. Masks are still compulsory indoors for people over the age of 8, and are recommended for everyone over the age of 6. https://archive.vn/eMANS

On October 14th, 2021, the Corona Commission classifies all of Austria as high risk. The federal states of Carinthia, Lower Austria, Upper Austria and Styria are also rated as having a high risk. Burgenland as well as Tyrol, Vorarlberg and Vienna are rated with medium risk. Salzburg is classified as very high risk.    The classification for the education sector is still risk level I for Vorarlberg and risk level II for all other federal states.     Source: https://archive.vn/C5hBO#selection-543.0-563.129 [Corona traffic light map]

"From week 38, the Corona Commission will determine the epidemiological risk for the educational institutions per federal state. On the basis of this classification, the Education Directorate determines the risk level for the federal state in agreement with the central office by ordinance. The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location."    *Vorarlberg*  In its meeting on October 14th, 2021, the Corona Commission determined that the schools in Vorarlberg will remain in risk level 1 .    Test and mask requirement:  Schoolchildren: There is no MNS requirement in the entire school building and there is no longer any compulsory test. However, antigen tests can still be carried out voluntarily. These are confirmed by the school in the sticker pass.  Teaching and administrative staff: There is no MNS obligation in the entire school building. For staff who have not been vaccinated / have not recovered, an external PCR test must still be submitted once a week; further antigen tests must be carried out at the school. Vaccinated and convalescents can voluntarily test themselves with antigen tests.  External persons must present a 3-G certificate and wear MNS during their entire stay at the school.     Arrangement of compulsory tests and masks:  If suspected cases arise during the voluntary antigen tests or during tests outside the school, all schools have the option of ordering a temporary test or mask compulsory for individual classes or the entire school for a maximum of one week . Such an arrangement requires the approval of the Education Directorate.    *Measures for the entire federal state of Styria*  From September 30, 2021 (until July 8, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    In order to minimize the risk of infection, the provider must implement the hygiene concepts and guidelines of the State of Styria, which include, in particular, requirements for ventilating, cleaning and disinfecting rooms as well as general hygiene measures for children, staff, external persons and accompanying persons.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  External persons must wear an FFP2 mask in the facility.  A valid Corona test pass (documentation issued by the school on the evidence provided of a low epidemiological risk) is required to care for school-age children in after-school care centers. If no corona test pass can be presented, 3-G proof must be provided when entering the facility.    *Carinthia*  Additional measures in music schools apply to Carinthia.    Measures for the entire federal state of Carinthia  From September 13, 2021 (until February 13, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    The 3-G rule applies when entering child education and care facilities, as well as day-care centers and when staying in closed rooms in these facilities. If this is not provided, an MNS must be worn.  The provider of a facility must implement the requirements of the COVID-19 guidelines for child education and care facilities.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  The 3-G certificate is a prerequisite for caring for children in after-school care centers. If this cannot be achieved, the child has to wear an MNS.    *Measures for the entire federal state of Styria*  From September 30, 2021 (until July 8, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    In order to minimize the risk of infection, the provider must implement the hygiene concepts and guidelines of the State of Styria, which include, in particular, requirements for ventilating, cleaning and disinfecting rooms as well as general hygiene measures for children, staff, external persons and accompanying persons.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  External persons must wear an FFP2 mask in the facility.  A valid Corona test pass (documentation issued by the school on the evidence provided of a low epidemiological risk) is required to care for school-age children in after-school care centers. If no corona test pass can be presented, 3-G proof must be provided when entering the facility.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/i1aIC - Vorarlberg  https://archive.vn/tfL5J - Carinthia  https://archive.vn/vhzaV#selection-809.0-809.28 - Risk levels in Upper Austria  https://archive.vn/77eIK - COVID-19 agricultural school ordinance 2021/22 applies to Salzburg   https://archive.vn/Jmj3m - Styria  https://archive.vn/cN2uW - Vienna  https://archive.vn/dAqZ5 - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/v9L39 - Good starting conditions for the winter semester 2021/22 - 80 percent of the students vaccinated  https://archive.vn/fmtyw - Coronavirus - Current Measures

Customer areas  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores.   When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services may only let in customers if they can present 3-G evidence. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    At work  Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.  The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    Leisure, sport and culture    leisure  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:     Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks  Baths and facilities   Dance schools  Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos  Show mines  Facilities for the practice of prostitution  Indoor playgrounds  Paintball systems  Museum railways  Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens  The following applies in this area:    Customers must show a 3-G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.  Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    Culture  Unvaccinated persons must wear an FFP2 mask in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives.  For cultural institutions in which mainly get-togethers take place, such as theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.  Sports  The 3-G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   All sports are permitted, and contact sports are again possible.  Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.  There are detailed regulations for the exercise of sports by top athletes.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/dAqZ5 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/G1slX [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

At work   â¢  Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.   â¢  The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.   â¢  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.   â¢  By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    Customer areas   â¢  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores.    â¢  When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.   â¢  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services may only let in customers if they can present 3-G evidence. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    3-G rule  The 3-G rule applies in the following areas:     â¢  gastronomy   â¢  Body-hugging services   â¢  Hotel and lodging   â¢  Leisure facilities (e.g. dance schools, zoos)   â¢  Cultural establishments    â¢  Non-public sports facilities   â¢  Meetings (from a number of participants of more than 100 people)   â¢  Trade and consumer fairs, congresses   â¢  Coaches and excursion boats    In addition, the 3G rule continues to apply in the following areas and for the following people:    In the provision of mobile care and support services   â¢  For visitors and employees of retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled   â¢  For residents for new admission in old people's and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled   â¢  For visitors and employees of hospitals or health resorts   â¢  For employees from other locations where health services are provided.    The following applies as evidence of a low epidemiological risk:   â¢  Evidence of negative testing for SARS-CoV-2   â¢  Medical confirmation of a past infection   â¢  Separation notice   â¢  Vaccination certificate   â¢  Proof of neutralizing antibodies    The certificates for vaccinated, recovered and tested persons are on an equal footing, but differ in their validity period    Sources:  https://archive.vn/3dN2m [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/ZM5VV [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

At work [please note these guidelines include some which will be introduced from 1 November onwards]   â¢  Employees, owners and operators are only allowed to enter workplaces where physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out if they have a 3G certificate. Contacts within the meaning of the first sentence do not include a maximum of two physical contacts per day that take place outdoors and each do not last longer than 15 minutes.   â¢  Up to and including November 14th, employees, owners and operators who do not provide a 3G certificate are required to wear an FFP2 mask. From November 15th, a workplace may only be entered with valid 3G proof without exception.   â¢  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.   â¢  With regard to the wearing of a mask and the submission of evidence of a low epidemiological risk, stricter regulations that go beyond this ordinance can be provided in justified cases.    Customer areas   â¢  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores (including sales outlets of food producers and petrol stations with affiliated sales outlets for groceries).    â¢  When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who do not provide 3G proof must wear an FFP2 mask.   â¢  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services is only allowed to let customers in if they can present a 3G certificate. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    Leisure, sport and culture    *Leisure*  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:    â¢  Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks   â¢  Baths   â¢  Dance schools   â¢  Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos   â¢  Show mines   â¢  Facilities for the practice of prostitution   â¢  Indoor playgrounds   â¢  Paintball systems   â¢  Museum railways   â¢  Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens    The following applies in this area:   â¢  Customers must show a 3G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.   â¢  Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    *Culture*  In museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, people who do not provide 3G proof must wear an FFP2 mask.  For cultural institutions in which mainly get-togethers take place, such as theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.    *Sports*  The 3G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.    Top athletes:  When top athletes practice sports, the responsible doctor must develop a COVID-19 prevention concept and monitor compliance with it on an ongoing basis.  Top athletes have to show a 3G certificate for training and competitions if physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out.  If a SARS-CoV-2 infection becomes known to an athlete, supervisor or trainer, all athletes, supervisors and trainers must undergo a molecular biological test or an antigen test for the presence of a SARS-CoV- 2 to undergo infection.    Gastronomy and accommodation    *Gastronomy*  When visiting a restaurant, the following rules must be observed:   â¢  3-G rule in catering establishments.   â¢  2.5G proof for establishments in the hospitality industry in which an increased mix and interaction of customers is to be expected, such as discos, clubs, aprÃ¨s-ski bars and dance halls in particular.    The operators of catering establishments must also ensure the following:   â¢  Self-service buffets can be operated subject to hygiene requirements.   â¢  Every catering business must create a prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.   â¢  Mandatory collection of customer data.   â¢  The 3-G rule does not apply to the pick-up of food and drinks, as well as snack bars and catering stands. Customers have to wear a mask in closed rooms.    *Night gastronomy*  Access to night-time catering, establishments in the hospitality industry in which an increased mix and interaction of customers is to be expected, such as discotheques, clubs, aprÃ¨s-ski bars and dance halls, is for vaccinated and convalescent people, as well as people with current negative PCR- Test result (max. 72 hours old) possible (2.5G proof).    *Accommodation*  The accommodation establishments are allowed to reopen under Covid conditions. To do this, the operators must: draw up a COVID-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.   â¢  The 3G rule applies when entering for the first time. If the validity expires during the stay, a new proof must be provided.   â¢  For the use of the culinary offer in hotels and accommodation establishments, the regulations of the catering trade apply. The 3G rule must be observed for the use of gastronomy, wellness and fitness offers.   â¢  Mandatory collection of customer data.   â¢  Supervised camping or caravan sites, shelters and cabin ships are also considered to be accommodation facilities.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/vgVms - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/nmP8T - Coronavirus - Current Measures

New regulations in the workplace from 01.11:  â¢	3-G proof at the workplace if contact with other people cannot be ruled out there  o	With 3-G proof, release from the mask requirement  o	Transition period up to and including November 14th: without 3-G proof, FFP2 masks are mandatory  â¢	3-G obligation for top athletes: inside  â¢	Increased test intensity for unvaccinated and unrecovered employees: inside the health and care sector  â¢	Access to workplaces in the health and care sector only with 3-G proof  â¢	Mouth and nose protection is mandatory in addition to the 3-G certificate in old people's and nursing homes as well as in hospitals  â¢	Furthermore, FFP2 mask compulsory for customers and visitors in places to cover necessary basic needs (e.g. supermarkets, pharmacies, public transport), in care and health facilities in addition to 3G  â¢	3-G proof or FFP2 mask in other customer areas (e.g. non-essential retail, travel agencies, museums)  â¢	Furthermore, no mask requirement in 3-G settings (e.g. gastronomy, accommodation providers, theaters, hairdressers, events)    Sources:  https://archive.vn/nmP8T [Coronavirus - Current Measures]  https://archive.vn/SXpx3 [FAQ]  https://web.archive.org/web/20211101214354/https://www.bma.gv.at/Services/News/Coronavirus/FAQ-3-G-am-Arbeitsplatz.html [FAQ]

The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    At work  â¢	Employees, owners and operators are only allowed to enter workplaces where physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out if they have a 3G certificate. Contacts within the meaning of the first sentence do not include a maximum of two physical contacts per day that take place outdoors and each do not last longer than 15 minutes.  â¢	Up to and including November 14th, employees, owners and operators who do not provide a 3G certificate are required to wear an FFP2 mask. From November 15th, a workplace may only be entered with valid 3G proof without exception.  â¢	The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  â¢	With regard to the wearing of a mask and the submission of evidence of a low epidemiological risk, stricter regulations that go beyond this ordinance can be provided in justified cases.    Leisure, sport and culture    leisure  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:   â¢	Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks  â¢	Baths  â¢	Dance schools  â¢	Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos  â¢	Show mines  â¢	Facilities for the practice of prostitution  â¢	Indoor playgrounds  â¢	Paintball systems  â¢	Museum railways  â¢	Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens    The following applies in this area:  â¢	Customers must show a 3G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.  â¢	Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    Culture  â¢	In museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, people who do not provide 3G proof must wear an FFP2 mask.  â¢	For cultural institutions in which mainly get-togethers take place, such as theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.    Sports  â¢	The 3G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   â¢	Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.  â¢	Top athletes:  	o	When top athletes practice sport, the responsible doctor must develop a COVID-19 prevention concept and monitor compliance with it on an ongoing basis.  	o	Top athletes have to show a 3G certificate for training and competitions if physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out.  	o	If a SARS-CoV-2 infection becomes known to an athlete, supervisor or trainer, all athletes, supervisors and trainers must undergo a molecular biological test or an antigen test for the presence of a SARS-CoV- 2 to undergo infection.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/J7wJi - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/ouA5Z - Current Measures

Clearance and mouth and nose protection  There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.  In everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and grocery stores, an FFP2 mask must be worn again instead of the previous MNS wearing obligation.  In addition, the wearing of an FFP2 mask in trade and cultural institutions becomes an obligation for unvaccinated people. Wearing an FFP2 mask is recommended for people who have been vaccinated.  Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    2nd amendment to the 2nd COVID-19 - Measures Ordinance  Wearing an FFP 2 mask is compulsory in food retailing, including sales outlets of food producers and petrol stations with associated sales outlets for food, pharmacies, banks, post offices and public transport.  â¢For those who have not been vaccinated or who have not recovered It is compulsory for people to wear an FFP 2 mask in the entire trade, the day-care facilities in care for the elderly and in the disabled area, as well as cultural facilities (museums, libraries, theaters, cinemas, etc.).    Mask requirement in Vienna    In Vienna, the mask requirement applies in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, as well as institutions for religious practice.    Sources:   https://archive.vn/dAqZ5#selection-1711.0-1711.39 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/G1slX#selection-1537.0-1601.180 [Coronavirus - Current Measures]  https://archive.vn/XEvAR [Vienna]

Measures for the entire state of Salzburg  From October 18, 2021, additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19:  â¢ In addition to the FFP2 mask requirement in public pharmacies, food retailers, banks, and post offices, there is still an FFP2 mask requirement without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard  for all customers in the  customer areas of business premises in closed rooms and in connecting structures that are structurally connected Business premises (e.g. shopping centers, market halls).  â¢ The FFP2 mask requirement also applies to body-hugging services and to all cultural institutions.  â¢ Employees in retail, body-friendly services and cultural institutions are exempt from this.    Source: https://archive.vn/tYjaF [Measures for the entire state of Salzburg]

Measures for the entire federal state of Carinthia  From October 18, 2021 (until December 31, 2021), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in inpatient retirement homes and care facilities:    Visitors are only permitted to enter stationary residential and care facilities for the elderly if they can present 2G evidence or a negative PCR test, the acceptance of which is not older than 72 hours.     In cases that are particularly worthy of consideration, in which visitors cannot show 2G evidence or a negative PCR test, a SARS-CoV-2 antigen test can be carried out under the supervision of a person authorized to do so by the operator of a nursing home. The negative test result must be kept available for the duration of the stay. This also applies to external service providers when there is contact with residents.    Employees may only enter inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly if they can present proof of 2G or a weekly negative PCR test, the acceptance of which is not older than 72 hours.    Source: https://archive.vn/lwufm [overview of current measures in Carinthia]

No change as per previous update.    Quote: Citizens and legal residents of Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Canada, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Israel, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Russia, Serbia, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the UAE, the UK, and the US are allowed to enter by air without the previously required special permission if they meet the following conditions:  - All passengers of 18 years and older must possess official documentation (i.e., COVID Passport) demonstrating that they have either been fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19. Additionally, a negative result from a PCR test not older than 72 hours is required.  - All passengers between 1 and 18 years of age must possess a negative result from a PCR test not older than 72 hours.  - No such documents are required for infants aged less than one year.    Returning Azerbaijani nationals require only a negative result from a PCR test within 72 hours prior to the flight.     Land and maritime borders remain closed, air travel is the only option to enter. A limited number of commercial and charter flights are operating to and from selected destinations. Passengers on domestic flights are no longer required to provide a test, but those flying into Baku's Heydar Aliyev International Airport (GYD) will undergo PCR tests upon arrival."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211012222802/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/528426/azerbaijan-government-to-ease-certain-covid-19-related-restrictions-effective-oct-1-update-38

Travellers can now visit Azerbaijan under the following conditions:  submission of an official document issued by the relevant country (COVID passport) on complete vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 for passengers over 18 years of age and a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before the flight  submission of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before the flight for passengers aged from 1 to 18 years.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211106152927/https://azerbaijan.travel/covid-19-en

Current economic measures in place have been extended to December 31, 2021. The five socio-economic support measures that are extended until December 31, 2021 are as follows: Temporary unemployment due to force majeure for all sectors, The simple crisis gateway right for all sectors from a loss of 65% of turnover, A monthly bonus of 25 euros for beneficiaries of integration income, a GRAPA or an ARR Financial support for rail operators (people and freight) and Maintaining the VAT rate at 6% on hydroalcoholic gel and masks    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003171205/https://www.premier.be/fr/prolongation-ciblee-des-mesures-de-soutien-economique-jusquau-31-decembre-2021

Starting October 26, the mask requirement now applies uniformly in all of Belgium. It is required in the following situations; in public transportation and in medical and non-medical contact occupations, stores and shopping malls; health care facilities; areas accessible to the public in companies, public buildings, court buildings; establishments for cultural, festive, sporting and recreational activities, including theaters, concert halls, cinemas, museums, indoor theme and amusement parks, indoor fitness centers and sports centers; libraries, toy and game libraries and media libraries; worship centers.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104151557/https://www.commissioner.brussels/en/updates-covid-19/item/885-uniform-measures-in-belgium

Authorities in Bulgaria have amended international entry restrictions imposed to combat the spread of COVID-19. As of Oct. 12, entry is permitted for UK travelers arriving from the UK, a European Union member state, the European Economic Area, or Switzerland provided they present a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival, as well as a certificate of COVID-19 vaccination or recovery; travelers that do not possess a certificate indicating COVID-19 vaccination or recovery may enter Bulgaria but must self-isolate for 10 days upon arrival.    Authorities have also moved France, Monaco, Portugal, Cyprus, and Iceland into the green list of countries while moving Malaysia, Eswatini, Iran, Macedonia, Kosovo, Kazakhstan, the U.S., and Ireland to the orange list of countries. Barbados, Antigua and Barbuda, Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Slovakia, and Singapore are to be considered red-list countries from Oct. 13.    Authorities in Bulgaria classify countries as green, orange, or red based on local disease activity and accordingly apply differing entry restrictions. Travelers from green and orange countries can enter upon presenting a valid EU Digital COVID certificate or similar document confirming vaccination against COVID-19, recovery from COVID-19, or a recent negative test for the disease. Travelers without such documentation must isolate for 10 days on arrival, though isolation can be ended early following receipt of a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours after arrival.    Travel from red countries is permitted for EU citizens, their families, and persons traveling for selected essential purposes only. Permitted travelers from red countries must present a valid EU Digital COVID certificate or similar document indicating vaccination against or recovery from COVID-19, in addition to a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival and certified by a valid EU Digital COVID certificate or similar document. Limited categories of travelers are permitted to enter by only satisfying the PCR test requirement, but must self-isolate for 10 days on arrival.      Citizens and residents of Romania, Turkey, Greece, Serbia, and North Macedonia who also travel daily or weekly to Bulgaria for work or study may enter the country without restrictions; these travelers do not need to show COVID-19-related documentation to enter Bulgaria. The same rules apply to Bulgarian citizens and residents who travel daily or weekly for work or study to these five neighboring countries. Freight transporters and aircraft crews are also exempt from the documentation requirement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101215018/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/533771/bulgaria-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-entry-restrictions-as-of-oct-12-easing-entry-controls-for-uk-travelers-update-36

PCR testing is widely available at sites across the country, including hospitals and private laboratories. Currently 100 hospitals and laboratories in Bulgaria are officially accredited by the Ministry of Health. A full list is published in Health Order ? ??-01-774/16.09.2021 ?. The fee is generally approximately $100 and is fully covered by . It is preferable, to make an appointment by phone as most of the hospitals have specific time slots during which citizens can get tested. Tests results can be checked online but originals are usually stamped and collected in person.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211101214710/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Contact Tracing is implemented by the RHIs. Someone who has come in close contact with a confirmed case is registered and must be tested.     https://archive.vn/ZAmWP

All persons must wear a mask that covers their mouth and nose in all indoor public spaces as well as in open public spaces where there is a crowd of people and it is not possible to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m. Scarves or substitute face coverings are no longer allowed in place of a mask. All persons must cover their mouth and nose with a mask or covering on all public transportation including while in railway, bus and metro stations, and airports etc.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101214710/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to UNESCO data schools are open across the country.    https://archive.vn/XAwIP
Shops are largely open although may be operating reduced hours and with social distancing restrictions. Further changes could be introduced at short notice.     https://archive.vn/ufa3V

Public gatherings of more than 100 people in the open air and of more than 50 people in closed rooms are prohibited. A distance of 2 m must be kept. This does not apply to parliamentary sessions. Exceptionally, a maximum of 100 people may be present in theaters and cinemas, at congresses, conferences and other educational events. It is also possible to organize larger gatherings (max. 150 people indoors and max. 300 people outdoors) under specially defined conditions, ie all participants need either an antigen or PCR test, not older than 48 hours , or a certificate of their recovery, not older than six months, or a certificate of a complete vaccination. All epidemiological measures must be observed. Organizers are obliged to notify the cantonal health ministries of all planned events.    https://archive.vn/x2eon

Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. - Entry into the Republic of Belarus through a land border for foreign citizens has been suspended. There is a narrow list of concessions, including for holders of permanent/temporary residency - you should check the State Border Committee website for details.  - Foreign arrivals above the age of six, without vaccine certification must have a medical PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) certificate showing a negative coronavirus test result, issued no later than 72 hours before entry. This requirement does not apply to holders of permanent or temporary residency in Belarus.   - Arrivals who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 are not required to self-isolate for 7 days or produce a negative PCR test certificate provided the second dose was administered more than 1 but less than 12 months before arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233747/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belarus/entry-requirements

No policy change. Tests are generally available in Switzerland.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211022160145/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/testen.html

Tests are generally available in Switzerland. This is what can be read on governmental sources regarding the financial coverage of the tests:    "The federal government covers the costs of individual PCR tests in the following cases:    You are being tested because you have symptoms.  You have received a notification from the SwissCovid app.  You have been instructed by a cantonal authority or a doctor to perform a test.  The federal government does not cover the costs of PCR tests in the following cases:    You need a negative test result for travel purposes. In this case, we recommend that you inform yourself in advance how much the test will cost."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211113031533/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/testen.html

No policy change. This is what can be found on governmental sources:  "Contact tracing identifies people who have had close contact with people who have been infected with the coronavirus. The SwissCovid app supports this process, establishing whether close contact has taken place and giving rapid notification if there is a potential risk of infection."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211022160153/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/swisscovid-app-und-contact-tracing.html

No policy change. The Swiss government continues using the SwissCovid app to trace new spikes.    "Contact tracing identifies people who have had close contact with people who have been infected with the coronavirus. The SwissCovid app supports this process, establishing whether close contact has taken place and giving rapid notification if there is a potential risk of infection."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211113031752/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/swisscovid-app-und-contact-tracing.html

"Masks must be worn in publicly accessible indoor spaces, for example in shops or in enclosed areas of public vehicles. Always wear a mask indoors when you are away from home, no certificate is required and you are unable to maintain social distancing of 1.5 metres from other people at all times." Unvaccinated pupils over the age of 12 and primary and lower secondary school staff are strongly encouraged to take a test once per week. The Danish travel restrictions classify all countries and regions into four colour categories: green, yellow, orange and red. These categories determine which rules apply to you.     People coming in from countries in the red zone have the strictest guidelines requiring: a test required prior to boarding aircraft, test and isolation required after entry, with foreigners requiring a worthy purpose for entry to Denmark, and to take test prior to entry to Denmark (EU Digital COVID Certificate)    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211005165127/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/categorization-of-countries

There are new entry requirements in Denmark which came into effect on October 25.    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents in EU/Schengen or an OECD-country*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country without testing or self-isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark from an EU/Schengen country or within 24 hours after arrival  2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country with testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival  3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211030131742/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

Rules were updated on November 3    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen can enter Denmark. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark  or within 24 hours after arrival    2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival    3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104165021/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. People are also advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when visiting the hospital. However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017171233/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Masks are recommended in educational institutions. Workplaces are open but the employers must evaluate the risks present in the working environment and enact measures to lower the risks: these measures can include requirement to wear a mask, testing, vaccination, re-organisation of work...    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112151438/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/work-during-the-emergency-situation

People over 12 must present a COVID certificate and masks must be worn indoors.   Up to 6000 people may participate indoors and up to 12 000 people outdoors.  Since November 1, the indoor events have to end by 23pm and can only start after 6 am  https://web.archive.org/web/20211109210931/https://www.kriis.ee/en/restrictions-force
Up to 6000 people may gather indoors and up to 12 000 people outdoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211109210931/https://www.kriis.ee/en/restrictions-force

No restriction on internal movements    https://web.archive.org/web/20211109210931/https://www.kriis.ee/en/restrictions-force

Restrictions depend on the country of arrival. Some travelers coming from some of the red countries are not allowed to enter Estonia without a proper reason. Travelers coming from other specific countries must self-isolate for 10 days. Others will only need to take a test.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211109214640/https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-self-isolation-requirements-passengers

There is no income support provided, only sickness benefits.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211112154333/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
There is no announcement regarding debt relief for households.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211112153030/https://valitsus.ee/en/node/24880
There is a coordinated public campaign with information on the government website  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018151838/https://www.kriis.ee/en/emergency-situation-estonia

In most cases, family physicians or the Health Board must refer their patients to testing. Specific providers can also provide tests for a fee to anyone who wants to be tested.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211112160814/https://www.terviseamet.ee/en/testing-virus

Employers in both the private and public sector are recommended to organize remote work in regions currently in the acceleration and community transmission phase. However, this policy would be phased out on October 15    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003180557/https://stm.fi/etatyot-koronavirustilanteessa

The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health have examined the grounds for the validity of the national telework recommendation and propose that the telework recommendation end on 15 October. However, the Department of Health and Welfare estimates recommends the extension of the telework recommendation one month onwards, until October 31. However, this is not necessary in areas that are considered low-risk in terms of Covid 19 transmission rates. Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017163157/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021. The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021. The Finnish Institute of Health recommends the use of facemasks especially in public indoor spaces where many people are in close proximity to each other as well as those who are on their way to get tested for the coronavirus, and those who are waiting for the results of a test, if there is an urgent reason to go outside the home. Those over the age of 12 who have not received two doses of COVID-19 vaccine or who have not had a COVID-19 infection within the past six months are also specially recommended to use the facemasks. No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence, and as of 11/5 are:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.  - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.  - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname and Turkey.    Travelers from Green list countries aged twelve years or older are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons, but are required to present:    - proof of having received all the doses prescribed for one of the vaccines approved by the European Medicines Agency  - or the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 72 hours before departure.  - or a recovery certificate dating back more than eleven days and less than six months (this document is issued to the person who has been contaminated by Covid-19 on presentation of a positive result in an RT-PCR screening examination or an antigen test).    A reinforced regimen is in place for the United Kingdom, with a test initially required (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours for unvaccinated people.    For travelers from Orange list countries:    Unvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories must present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test performed less than 72 hours or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 48 hours before the flight. They may be subject to a random antigen test upon arrival.  Vaccinated travellers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime.  Unvaccinated travellers are subject to the regime of compelling reasons and will have to undertake self-isolation for 7 days. The list of compelling reasons is specified in thetravel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    For travel from Red list countries:   Unvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories:  - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons, the list of which is specified in the travel and travel certificate drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.  - must present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight.  - will be subject to a mandatory antigen test upon arrival.  - will be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine,controlled by the security forces.    Those travelers from countries that must demonstrate a "compelling reason" may be denied entry if their journey does not meet the requirements deailed at https://web.archive.org/web/20211102144014/https://www.interieur.gouv.fr/Actualites/L-actu-du-Ministere/Attestation-de-deplacement-et-de-voyage     https://web.archive.org/web/20211105173602/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

RT-PCR and lateral flow tests are widely available, costs covered by health insurance when conditions are met - https://web.archive.org/web/20211017035739/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

RT-PCR and lateral flow tests remain generally available, but the cost of such tests are no longer universally covered by health insurance as of 15 October.     Prime Minister Jean Castex announced that "It is no longer legitimate to pay excessively for comfort tests at taxpayers' expense. But tests will continue to be reimbursed on medical grounds, either without a prescription for people already vaccinated or on prescription for others. We also want to keep it free for minors. The logic is to reimburse tests related to truly medical reasons, and to continue to encourage vaccination."    Testing costs will be covered by insurance for people:     - having a complete vaccination schedule (or a contraindication to vaccination)  - minors  - identified for "contact tracing" by the Health Insurance agency  - during collective screening campaigns (ARS, schools, etc.)  - symptomatic on medical prescription  - with a recovery certificate of less than six months    Tests required to obtain a Health Pass become chargeable as of 15 October.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20211020113443/https://www.gouvernement.fr/fin-de-la-gratuite-systematique-des-tests-covid-19

Vaccination is available to everyone aged 12 years and 2 months or older, and is mandatory for all staff working with vulnerable people (including home help staff, all employees of medical institutions, firefighters - full list available at archived link.)    Booster vaccines are recommended for people aged 65+ and people with comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19.     Janssen, AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211017035752/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is available to everyone aged 12 years and 2 months or older, and is mandatory for all staff working with vulnerable people (including home help staff, all employees of medical institutions, firefighters - full list available at archived link.)    Pfizer-BioNTech booster vaccines are recommended for people who received their last vaccination 6 months ago, or 4 weeks after vaccination with the Janssen vaccine, for the following groups of people:    - People aged 12-17 who are immunocompromised or comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19    - People aged 18 to 64 who:   -- have been vaccinated with the Janssem vaccine  -- are living with compromised immune systems or comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19, and those who live with them  -- health care professionals, home assistants, transport staff working with vulnerable people  -- firefighters    - people aged 65 or over     Janssen, AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211022163823/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In additions to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers. no policy change     Land borders of Georgia are open from June 1, 2021 in line with a decision made by the Inter-Agency Coordination Council. Border crossing is currently permitted to citizens of EU member states and 40 countries   in addition, as well as to individuals with a permission of residence. They need to present the following at the border crossing: document evidencing a full cycle of vaccination and a negative result of PCR test obtained in the past 72 hours, or alternatively present only a negative PCR test result obtained 72 hours prior to the visit to Georgia and get a repeated PCR test on the 3rd day of their stay in Georgia at their own expense.  Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.12-091850/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/shezgudvebi

Schools in Greece reopened Monday, a move that will lead to a new surge of COVID-19 among children and in the wider population. Infection rates in young people are already very high. According to the Ministry of Health, more than 12 percent of all cases occur among those aged under 17 and 38 percent among 18-to 39-year-olds.    https://web.archive.org/www.wsws.org/en/articles/2021/09/15/gree-s15.html

no policy change   At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    /web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella

Prohibition of any kind of gathering of citizens for over 9 people for any reason, both in public and in private."    https://web.archive.org/https://covid19.gov.gr/covid-map-en/

All unvaccinated people in Greece from Monday, September 13, will be allowed to board all means of transport for domestic travel between regions (airplanes, ferries, intercity trains and KTEL buses) only if they have a negative Covid-19 rapid antigen test result.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211022124338/https://news.gtp.gr/2021/09/13/covid-19-how-unvaccinated-greece-can-travel-by-land-air-sea-rules/

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

no policy change     Some regions continue with restrictions on activities:  Level 4 (red) of the Epidemiological Map of the country includes the Regional Units of Argolida and Evritania, while the validity of the special, local character, measures in the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion, as well as in the Municipality of Ikaria are extended.    It is recalled that the measures in force are the following:  Curfew from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in shops of sanitary interest and entertainment.  The measures are in effect from tomorrow, Friday, September 10 at 06.00 until Friday, September 16 at 6:00.  Also, it is reminded that both in these areas, as well as throughout the country, it is forbidden to conduct any form of events for any form of consideration, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210911005856/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-argolida-kai-eyrytania  https://web.archive.org/web/20210911002130/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 5 August, there are additional gathering restrictions in Sisimiut, Upernavik, Upernavik district and Aasiaat. A maximum of 20 persons may gather in these geographic areas, for both outdoor and indoor arrangements, events, and other public activities. Some public establishments may be required to limit access to fewer than 20 persons, depending on the size of their area. This is valid through 31 October.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315224140/https://blog.wego.com/greenland-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/

Persons 12 years of age and older who travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut to another place in Greenland, and who are not fully vaccinated, must go into quarantine for 14 days upon arrival to their destination, or go into quarantine until receiving a negative test result on a PCR test taken on the 5th day after departure from Nuuk or Sisimiut, at the earliest. This is valid through 30 November 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211103045826/https://visitgreenland.com/corona-faq/#toggle-id-13-closed

If you have not been vaccinated and travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut, you must be quarantined for five days and tested for COVID-19 when you arrive at your destination in Greenland. You must be tested on the 5th day or later after departure, and if your test is negative, you are considered not to be infected. If you do not allow yourself to be tested on the 5th day, you must stay in the same city for a minimum of 14 consecutive days prior to the trip before you can travel on to another city.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211111213824/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indenrigsrejser-i-gronland/

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. A face mask or shield is not required when using public transportation. You are advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when you visit the hospital.    However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210424102045/https://konzuliszolgalat.kormany.hu/europa-utazasi-tanacsok?dania

ZAGREB, Sept. 6 (Xinhua) -- Some 460,000 children went back to school in Croatia on Monday, as the country eased measures introduced to tackle COVID-19.    Students of different grades will be able to socialize with each other, and do sports together. Masks are still mandatory for students of above grade five if the distance between them in classrooms is less than 1.5 to 2 metres, and parents should take their children's temperature before going to school.    Teachers who are vaccinated will be able to work without masks, but those who are unvaccinated will have to wear one. Only vaccinated parents will be allowed to attend parents' meetings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211109112321/http://www.news.cn/english/2021-09/06/c_1310171927.htm

Schools and colleges are adapting to the situation on a daily basis, and in order to provide education to all students in educational institutions, a hybrid model of education has been introduced - some have continued classroom teaching and some have introduced online teaching to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The new condition is also the physical distance that everyone must adhere to, so in educational institutions it is precisely determined what the distance between the tables must be, when the masks must be worn and how long the school lesson or lecture will last. What is school without its students?    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112162611/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-skolovanju/13

In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interference by workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded. All recommendations for employees and employers in trade, catering facilities, measures for drivers in road freight transport or employees in the state administration, can be found here.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46

Gatherings - measures take effect tomorrow    Today, the Headquarters passed a new Decision which regulates, ie restricts gatherings, which will take effect tomorrow , and the most important changes are:    It is forbidden to hold all public events and gatherings indoors where more than 50 people are present in one place, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate , and the same is the responsibility of the civil headquarters. protection of local self-government units gave consent. (so far it referred to more than 100)  Measures are being tightened to hold all public events and gatherings indoors with more than 50 people, where, with the participation of the EU digital COVID certificate, it will be mandatory to use a medical mask or face mask and maintain the necessary physical distance . (so far this has not been mandatory for gatherings with the EU digital COVID certificate).  The measure of banning all public events and outdoor gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place is still valid, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate .  All ** public events and gatherings ** must end no later than 24.00 hours, which means that gatherings with EU digital COVID certificates for which the local headquarters has given consent for maintenance cannot last longer than 24.00 hours , nor professional artistic performances and programs, exhibitions in museum spaces and similar cultural events. * The only exceptions are cinema screenings that started before 23.00 and can end after 24.00. Also, wedding ceremonies where all those present have EU digital COVID certificates must end no later than 02.00 (so far they have not been limited in time), and additional time limits will be considered according to the epidemiological situation. *  congresses and conferences will be able to be held only if all those present have an EU digital COVID certificate , and the condition is that it is mandatory to use medical masks or face masks and to maintain physical distance.  Sports competitions will be able to be held in the presence of spectators only if everyone has EU digital COVID certificates (there is no possibility of attending up to 100 spectators with an epidemiological framework developed by the County Institute of Public Health and County Headquarters), and indoors spectators except the EU Digital COVID certification, you must also use medical masks or face masks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163612/https://www.koronavirus.hr/od-06-11-ogranicenja-za-okupljanja-a-od-15-11-covid-potvrde-u-drzavnim-i-javnim-slu%C5%BEbama-uklju%C4%8Dujuci-i-skole/992

We take increased care of hand hygiene on a daily basis, avoid touching our eyes, nose and mouth with dirty hands, and handling and direct contact should be kept to a minimum. Going out, visiting museums and entertainment in general are temporarily restricted, all in order to maximize the impact on preventing the spread of coronavirus indoors. During all events and trips, it is important to adhere to the prescribed measures and recommendations. Regarding occupational health, it is recommended to introduce work from home or shift work, in order to avoid unwanted situations as much as possible. In order to protect yourself and others, you avoid gatherings, but do not forget to help those who need help the most today, our elderly fellow citizens. It is primarily important for everyone to preserve health, because when a person is healthy - he can do a lot.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210827182507/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/185
